nodes.text: shows KMS’s pro forma income statement for 2020 along with how each line was determined. KMS is forecasting 18% growth in sales from 2019 to 2020. In addition to the sales forecast, we require three other details to prepare the pro forma income statement: costs excluding depreciation in 2019 as a percent of sales, depreciation as a percent of sales, and the tax rate. KMS’s info from
Costs excluding depreciation were 78% of sales.

config.activityTitle: KMS Designs’ Pro Forma Income Statement for 2020

nodes.text: The one final assumption we need to make is about our interest expense.

The interest expense should be interest paid on debt, net of interest earned on any invested cash—just as interest paid is tax deductible, interest earned is taxable—so KMS’s tax shield comes from its net interest expense. In order to focus on forecasting, we will assume that all cash held by KMS is a necessary part of its working capital needed for transactions. Thus, we assume that KMS holds all of its cash in a non-interest-bearing account. In
, we will discuss alternative ways to invest cash.
We assume for now that it will remain the same as in 2019 because we will determine if our debt needs will change as part of the forecasting process.
Based on our pro forma balance sheet, we are forecasting an increase in net income of

nodes.text: , which represents an 18.5% increase over 2019 net income.
This is higher than the sales growth of 18% because we assumed that interest expenses would not increase.
We now turn to forecasting the balance sheet to determine whether we will need any new financing in 2020 to pay for our growth. The net income we forecast in
will be one of the inputs to the pro forma balance sheet. The part of that net income not distributed as dividends will add to stockholders’ equity on the balance sheet.
KMS has just revised its sales forecast downward. If KMS expects sales to grow by only 10% next year, what are its costs, except for depreciation, projected to be?

nodes.text: . With this figure in hand and the information from
, we can use the percent of sales method to calculate KMS’s forecasted costs.
, we see that costs are 78% of sales. With forecasted sales of $82,378, that leads to forecasted costs except depreciation of

nodes.text: If costs remain a constant 78% of sales, then our best estimate is that they will be $64,255.
